awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2022 ACM International Conference on Underwater Networks and Systems (WUWNet’22)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supported the travel of 15 students to the 2022 Association for the ACM International Conference on Underwater Networks Systems (WUWNet) conference. The WUWNet conference has established itself as one of the premier technical venues in the field of underwater wireless networks and serves as a meeting point for researchers from academia and industry as well as practitioners in diverse fields of underwater communications and networking systems. The goal of WUWNet is to  bring together leading contributors from academia and industry working in diverse areas of underwater systems engineering for connecting the “Blue Economies.”  The conference regularly attracts world-leading researchers and practitioners to attend and present their work and attend panels and keynote sessions.   The focus of WUWNet’22 is threefold: (i)  Networking the Blue Economy; (ii)  Systems Research, Experimentation, Hands-on Evaluations; (iii)  Cross-disciplinary Wireless Research. The conference will have special plenary sessions for papers that fall under these broad categories, along with other regular sessions that encompass many other exciting developments in the Blue Tech domain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the project is to promote student participation in WUWNet'22. Participation in high-quality scientific meetings, such as WUWNet, is an extremely important part of the research training experiences.

The project's major activities included:

1) We took a multi-pronged approach to recruit applicants. NSF student travel support was advertised among WUWNet participants. Institutions that participated in the past WUWNet conferences were individually contacted. We reached out to all (student) authors who submitted papers to WUWNet'22 making them aware that they have an opportunity to attend the conference even if their papers are not accepted.  A webpage was created at the WUWNet'22 site: https://wuwnet.acm.org/2022/info/grant/. The NSF support was acknowledged at the conference website.

2) Fifteen (15) students were awarded an NSF student travel grant. We followed the NSF guidelines to grant travel support to two categories of applicants: first-time attendees and under-represented groups.

3) Travel reimbursements were processed shortly after the conference for each of the student travel grant awardees.

We followed the NSF guidelines to promote the participation of student scholars from diverse backgrounds:

1. A portion of the travel grants was reserved for first-time attendees who do not have an accepted paper. Undergraduates and beginning graduate students were strongly encouraged to apply.

2. A portion of the travel grants was reserved for under-represented groups (NSF definition: Women, persons with disabilities, and three racial and ethnic groups—blacks, Hispanics, and American Indians or Alaska Natives), who do not need to have an accepted paper.

Fourteen out of the fifteen total student travel grant awardees (including four female students) were in the category of first-time attendees. Four female students were allocated to the second category of the under-represented groups. Two first-time attendees without papers were among the awardees. Twelve students were graduate (two M.S., ten Ph.D.) and three undegraduate students. For two out of the three undegraduate students, WUWNet'22 was the first research conference they have ever attended.

Nearly all the awardees stayed all three-days at the conferences. A majority of the awardees presented demo and regular oral presentations during the regular paper session. They participated in technical discussions.  

The awardee from the University of Washington, Seattle, Justin Chan, won the best demo award for his demo "Underwater Communication on Smartphones and Smartwatches".


Last Modified: 07/02/2024
Modified by: Georgios Sklivanitis

Image
  • Closing ceremony at WUWNet'22 featuring members of the organizing committee, conference speakers, poster/demo presenters, student travel grant awardees including Justin Chan, (University of Washington) who received the Best demo award for "Underwater Communication on Smartphones and Smartwatches."
    WUWNet'22 Organizing Committee
    Public Domain
    Georgios Sklivanitis
    Closing ceremony at WUWNet'22
